date_of_birth.name: date_of_birth
date_of_birth.description: The date of birth of the candidate in ISO form.

name_first.name: name_first
name_first.description: The legal first name of the customer.

name_last.name: name_last
name_last.description: The legal middle name of the customer.

name_middle.name: name_middle
name_middle.description: The legal middle name of the customer.

passport.name: passport
passport.description: The passport number of the individual being verified. This is only used for verifying non-US customers.

ssn.name: ssn
ssn.description: This can be either the last 4 digits of the US Social Security Number or the whole SSN.

address_city.name: address_city
address_city.description: The city name of the customer. This is automatically normalized.

address_country_code.name: address_country_code
address_country_code.description: The country of the customer. Should be of the ISO code form.

address_postal_code.name: address_postal_code
address_postal_code.description:
The postal code of the person. Also known as a ZIP code.
The country of the customer. Should be of the ISO code form.

address_street1.name: address_street1
address_street1.description: The primary street address of the customer. This is automatically normalized.

address_street2.name: address_street2
address_street2.description: The second address line typically used for apartment or suite numbers. This is automatically normalized.

address_subdivision.name: address_subdivision
address_subdivision.description:
The subdivision of the entered country. For instance in the United States, this would be a 'state'.
The state of the customer. Should be of the FIPS code form. For example California would be CA.

note.name: note
note.description: You can store additional information about the candidate here such as your internal system's identifier for this individual. This will allow you to keep track of them.

address_street2.name: address_street2
address_street2.description: The second address line typically used for apartment or suite numbers. This is automatically normalized.

ip_address.name: ip_address
ip_address.description:
Your customers' IP address can be passed to us for storage purposes. Soon we will be using this information for anti-fraud and verification purposes. With this information we will be able to back-test your verifications when this feature is released.
Both IPv4 and IPv6 style IP addresses are acceptable.

note.name: note
note.description: You can store additional information about the candidate here such as your internal system's identifier for this individual. This will allow you to keep track of them.

phone_number.name: phone_number
phone_number.description:
If you pass in the phone number, we will use it as an additional 'positive' data point for the consumer. That is, if it is provided, it will help us identify them, but if we cannot, they will not be penalized.
Extra characters like parenthesis and dashes are accepted - can either contain the country code or not.

Authorization.name: Authorization
Authorization.description:
The Authorization field value consists of credentials
containing the authentication information of the user agent for the
realm of the resource being requested.

application/json.name: application/json
application/json.example:
{
  "object": "person",
  "id": "544744f43266330002010000",
  "created_at": 1413956852,
  "updated_at": 1413956984,
  "status": "valid",
  "livemode": true,
  "phone_number": null,
  "ip_address": "",
  "birth_day": 23,
  "birth_month": 8,
  "birth_year": 1993,
  "name_first": "John",
  "name_middle": null,
  "name_last": "Doe",
  "address_street1": "1 Infinite Loop",
  "address_street2": null,
  "address_city": "Cupertino",
  "address_subdivision": "CA",
  "address_postal_code": "95014",
  "address_country_code": "US",
  "document_type": "ssn",
  "document_value": "0000",
  "note": "ref-id:12345",
  "details": {
    "address": "no_match",
    "address_risk": "low",
    "identification": "partial_match",
    "date_of_birth": "partial_match",
    "ofac": "no_match",
    "pep": "no_match"
  },
  "question_sets": [
    "536c1532627463780b000000"
  ]
}

name_first.name: name_first
name_first.description: The legal first name of the customer.

name_last.name: name_last
name_last.description: The legal middle name of the customer.

document_type.name: document_type
document_type.description: Must be one of the document types described in the Documents section.

name_middle.name: name_middle
name_middle.description: The legal middle name of the customer.

document_value.name: document_value
document_value.description: The number associated with the form of documentation used.

birth_day.name: birth_day
birth_day.description: The integer associated with the day of birth.

birth_month.name: birth_month
birth_month.description: The integer associated with the month of birth.

address_street1.name: address_street1
address_street1.description: The primary street address of the customer. This is automatically normalized.

address_city.name: address_city
address_city.description: The city name of the customer. This is automatically normalized.

address_subdivision.name: address_subdivision
address_subdivision.description: The subdivision of the entered country. For instance in the United States, this would be a 'state'.

address_postal_code.name: address_postal_code
address_postal_code.description: The postal code of the person. Also known as a ZIP code.

address_country_code.name: address_country_code
address_country_code.description: The country of the customer. Should be of the ISO code form.

address_street2.name: address_street2
address_street2.description: The second address line typically used for apartment or suite numbers. This is automatically normalized.

ip_address.name: ip_address
ip_address.description:
Your customers' IP address can be passed to us for storage purposes. Soon we will be using this information for anti-fraud and verification purposes. With this information we will be able to back-test your verifications when this feature is released.
Both IPv4 and IPv6 style IP addresses are acceptable.

note.name: note
note.description: You can store additional information about the candidate here such as your internal system's identifier for this individual. This will allow you to keep track of them.

phone_number.name: phone_number
phone_number.description:
If you pass in the phone number, we will use it as an additional 'positive' data point for the consumer. That is, if it is provided, it will help us identify them, but if we cannot, they will not be penalized.
Extra characters like parenthesis and dashes are accepted - can either contain the country code or not.

methods.description: This endpoint creates a new person. The information will be run through our verification process and then returned with additional information that will help you determine the authenticity of the information given.

methods.description:
This endpoint will allow you to see a historical record of all verifications that you have completed.

The list is displayed in reverse chronological order (newer people appear first).

application/json.name: application/json
application/json.example:
{

methods.description: You can pull up a single person at any time (typically this is used for auditing purposes).

application/json.name: application/json
application/json.example:
{
  "object": "question_set",
  "id": "533ce7e5627463792f010000",
  "created_at": 1402450269,
  "updated_at": 1403742375,
  "livemode": false,
  "person_id": "530c48b2627463452b570000",
  "score": 60.0,
  "expired": false,
  "time_limit": 300,
  "questions": [
    {
      "id": 1,
      "question": "Which of these people do you know?",
      "answers": [
        { "id": 1, "answer": "Alain" },
        { "id": 2, "answer": "John" },
        { "id": 3, "answer": "Chris" },
        { "id": 4, "answer": "Connor" },
        { "id": 5, "answer": "None Of The Above" }
      ]
    }
  ]
}

person_id.name: person_id
person_id.description: The ID of the person, and thus the identity, on which to base the question sets. You can create multiple question sets using the same question set ID.

time_limit.name: time_limit
time_limit.description: How long after creating a question set that the `expired` boolean will remain `false`. This is inputted in seconds and defaults to `0`, which means no time limit. This allows you to make sure that your customer does not take too long to answer a question set.

methods.description: This method will create a new question set to ask your users. You can call this endpoint multiple times with the same person ID and the questions asked as well as the order that everything is presented in will be randomized.

application/json.name: application/json

methods.description:
List all question sets

This endpoint will allow you to see a historical record of all question sets that you have created.

The list is displayed in reverse chronological order (newer question sets appear first).

application/json.name: application/json
application/json.example:
{
  "object": "question_set",
  "id": "533ce7e5627463792f010000",
  "created_at": 1402450269,
  "updated_at": 1403742375,
  "livemode": false,
  "person_id": "530c48b2627463452b570000",
  "score": 60.0,
  "expired": false,
  "time_limit": 300,
  "questions": [
    {
      "id": 1,
      "question": "Which of these people do you know?",
      "answers": [
        { "id": 1, "answer": "Alain" },
        { "id": 2, "answer": "John" },
        { "id": 3, "answer": "Chris" },
        { "id": 4, "answer": "Connor" },
        { "id": 5, "answer": "None Of The Above" }
      ]
    }
  ]
}

methods.description:
Retrieve an existing question set

This allows you to retrieve a question set you have created. If you have already scored the question set, we will also return the last score of your submitted answers.

application/json.name: application/json
application/json.example:
{
  "object": "question_set",
  "id": "533ce7e5627463792f010000",
  "created_at": 1402450269,
  "updated_at": 1403742375,
  "livemode": false,
  "person_id": "530c48b2627463452b570000",
  "score": 60.0,
  "expired": false,
  "time_limit": 300,
  "questions": [
    {
      "id": 1,
      "question": "Which of these people do you know?",
      "answers": [
        { "id": 1, "answer": "Alain" },
        { "id": 2, "answer": "John" },
        { "id": 3, "answer": "Chris" },
        { "id": 4, "answer": "Connor" },
        { "id": 5, "answer": "None Of The Above" }
      ]
    }
  ]
}

answers.name: answers
answers.description: An array of objects containing question_id and answer_id pairs. This is the container for all of the user's answers.

answers[][question_id].name: answers[][question_id]
answers[][question_id].description: The ID of the question to which the user is responding. This ID is found in the response when creating a question set.

answers[][answer_id].name: answers[][answer_id]
answers[][answer_id].description: The ID of the answer that the user picks while answering questions. The ID is found in the response when creating a question set.

methods.description: Once the user has finished answering the questions, you will need to send us their answers so that we can score it. The scoring system will score it based on how many questions you submit, so if you would only like to ask 3 questions, only submit the 3 questions which you would like scored.

application/json.name: application/json

entity_name.name: entity_name
entity_name.description: This should exclude any legal endings like 'Co' or 'Inc' for best results.

tax_id.name: tax_id
tax_id.description: The tax ID should only include the digits of the ID with no extraneous characters like dashes.

incorporation_state.name: incorporation_state
incorporation_state.description: Can be either of ISO code form or the full length name of the state.

incorporation_country_code.name: incorporation_country_code
incorporation_country_code.description: Should be of the ISO alpha-2 code form.

incorporation_type.name: incorporation_type
incorporation_type.description: Must be one of the pre-defined incorporation types listed in the 'Incorporation types' table.

incorporation_day.name: incorporation_day
incorporation_day.description: The day in integer form of the company's incorporation.

incorporation_month.name: incorporation_month
incorporation_month.description: The month in integer form of the company's incorporation.

incorporation_year.name: incorporation_year
incorporation_year.description: The year in 4-digit integer form of the company's incorporation.

dbas.name: dbas
dbas.description: Both commas and spaces are acceptable for delimiting multiple names.

registration_number.name: registration_number
registration_number.description: Should only include the digits of the registration number with no extraneous characters like dashes.

email.name: email
email.description: Any form of valid email is accepted.

url.name: url
url.description: Can either contain protocol information or not (ex. www.example.com and http://www.example.com).

address_street1.name: address_street1
address_street1.description: The primary street address of the customer. This is automatically normalized.

address_city.name: address_city
address_city.description: The city name of the customer. This is automatically normalized.

address_subdivision.name: address_subdivision
address_subdivision.description: The state of the customer. Should be of the FIPS code form. For example California would be CA.

address_postal_code.name: address_postal_code
address_postal_code.description: The country of the customer. Should be of the ISO code form.

address_country_code.name: address_country_code
address_country_code.description: The country of the customer. Should be of the ISO code form.

address_street2.name: address_street2
address_street2.description: The second address line typically used for apartment or suite numbers. This is automatically normalized.

ip_address.name: ip_address
ip_address.description:
Your customers' IP address can be passed to us for storage purposes. Soon we will be using this information for anti-fraud and verification purposes. With this information we will be able to back-test your verifications when this feature is released.
Both IPv4 and IPv6 style IP addresses are acceptable.

note.name: note
note.description: You can store additional information about the candidate here such as your internal system's identifier for this individual. This will allow you to keep track of them.

phone_number.name: phone_number
phone_number.description:
If you pass in the phone number, we will use it as an additional 'positive' data point for the consumer. That is, if it is provided, it will help us identify them, but if we cannot, they will not be penalized.
Extra characters like parenthesis and dashes are accepted - can either contain the country code or not.

methods.description:
Create a new company

This endpoint creates a new company. The information will be run through our company verification process and then returned with additional information that will help you determine the authenticity of the information given.

Please be aware that the response time can sometimes be more than 6 seconds due to the speed of some government data sources.

application/json.name: application/json

methods.description:
List all companies

This endpoint will allow you to see a historical record of all company verifications that you have completed.

The list is displayed in reverse chronological order (newer company verifications appear first).

application/json.name: application/json

methods.description:
Retrieve an existing company

You can pull up a single company verification at any time (typically this is used for auditing purposes).

methods.description:
Edit a candidate
If you'd like to amend the information associated with a candidate, you can modify it using this route. For instance, if your candidate changes addresses or you learn additional information about them. Only the information you send us will be updated - the rest will remain the same.

application/json.name: application/json
application/json.example:
{
  "object" : "candidate" ,
  "id" : "544aba053163310002630500" ,
  "deleted": true,
  "created_at" : 1414183429 ,
  "updated_at" : 1414183429 ,
  "livemode" : true ,
  "note" : "55555555" ,
  "ssn" : "0002" ,
  "passport" : null ,
  "date_of_birth" : "1940-08-11" ,
  "name_first" : "John" ,
  "name_middle" : null ,
  "name_last" : "Bredenkamp" ,
  "address_street1" : null ,
  "address_street2" : null ,
  "address_city" : "Harare" ,
  "address_subdivision" : null ,
  "address_postal_code" : null ,
  "address_country_code" : "AR"
}

methods.description:
Delete a candidate
This endpoint allows you to remove a candidate from our system. If you have signed up for continuous verification, then the deleted candidate will no longer be scanned.

application/json.name: application/json
application/json.example:
{
  "object" : "candidate" ,
  "id" : "544aba053163310002630500" ,
  "created_at" : 1414183429 ,
  "updated_at" : 1414183429 ,
  "livemode" : true ,

  "address_postal_code" : null ,
  "address_country_code" : "AR"
}

methods.description:
Retrieve an existing candidate

This endpoint allows you to retrieve the record of a candidate using their stored candidate_id.

application/json.name: application/json
application/json.example:
[
  {
    "object": "candidate",
    "id": "544aba053163310002630500",
    "created_at": 1414183429,
    "updated_at": 1414183429,
    "livemode": true,
    "note": null,
    "ssn": null,
    "passport": null,
    "date_of_birth": null,
    "name_first": "John",
    "name_middle": null,
    "name_last": "Bredenkamp",
    "address_street1": null,
    "address_street2": null,
    "address_city": null,
    "address_subdivision": null,
    "address_postal_code": null,
    "address_country_code": "ZW"
  },

methods.description:
View a candidate's revision history

We store a complete revision history of a candidate's edits. This allows you to maintain a full audit trail of when and how you update a client's profile over time.

The latest revision is presented at the top of the array, and the original is at the end of the array.

application/json.name: application/json
application/json.example:
{
  "object" : "list" ,
  "data" : [
    {
      "object" : "candidate" ,
      "id" : "544aba053163310002630500" ,
      "created_at" : 1414183429 ,
      "updated_at" : 1414183429 ,
      "livemode" : true ,
      "note" : "55555555" ,
      "ssn" : "0002" ,
      "passport" : null ,
      "date_of_birth" : "1940-08-11" ,
      "name_first" : "John" ,
      "name_middle" : null ,
      "name_last" : "Bredenkamp" ,
      "address_street1" : null ,
      "address_street2" : null ,
      "address_city" : "Harare" ,
      "address_subdivision" : null ,
      "address_postal_code" : null ,
      "address_country_code" : "AR"
    }
  ]
}

methods.description:
View a candidate's past hits

Whenever a search is executed for a candidate, we store the results of that search with timestamps of when those hits occurred. This endpoint allows you to view all historical watchlist hits for a given candidate.

application/json.name: application/json

candidate_id.name: candidate_id
candidate_id.description: The ID the candidate you have created. We search on all of the information provided in the associated profile.

match_type.name: match_type
match_type.description: Can be either the value person or company and will restrict the search to only search for people or entities on the watchlists.

similarity_threshold.name: similarity_threshold
similarity_threshold.description: The sensitivity of search results. Expects a float between 0.0 and 1.0 where 1.0 is exact matches only and 0.0 is lenient matching. The default value is 0.7.

methods.description: This endpoint creates a new verification. The information will be run through our verification process and then returned with additional information that will help you determine the authenticity of the information given.

documentation.title: Headline
documentation.content: BlockScore is a customer authentication and verification service that aims to assists users with handling the regulatory compliance issues surrounding international payment and transfers. The BlockScore API uses REST calls and allows users to submit data for authentication, off-load data, verify passports, and perform other tasks. An account, and an API key are required for use. SSL is required for all calls.
